text: Devon used the shapes from Problem 3.1. He suggested starting with a triangle.

Devon’s Strategy

The Sum of the Angles of a Triangle

I began by drawing irregular triangles. I tore the corners off the triangle and then rearranged them. The angles form a straight line or a straight angle. The sum of the angles of triangle are 180º.

Make a prediction

  • Does Devon's strategy make sense? Will it work on other triangles? Other polygons.
Answers will vary based on students' prior experiences.

Conduct an experiment

Equipment

  • A copy of the shapes from Problem 3.1.

Directions (individually, with a partner, or small group)

  • Tear off each angle and rearrange them around a point
  • Record the following information in a table.

Digital Note: Use the "duplicate" feature with the shapes provided below. Rotate the duplicated shapes to center one of each angle around a point.

Analyze the data

  • What patterns do you observe in the table? Does it agree with your prediction?
As you increase the number of sides by one, the angle sum increases by 180. Looking at this pattern in the table, we can see that (n – 2)180 = angle sum.

This gives a good opportunity to revisit the Distributive Property and early work on equivalent expressions from the Factoring in Structure Unit of Grade 6.

Note: At this point we do not expect students to have a deductive argument justifying their formula, just an observation about the pattern in the table values.

(number of sides – 2) • 180 = angle sum

or, in equation form
• What is the sum of the angles of an octagon? Nonagon? Decagon? N-gon?
• What is the angle measure of regular polygons? Octagon? Nonagon? Decagon? N-gon?
For regular polygons, we can take the angle sum and divide it by the number of angles, which is the same as the number of sides, to get the measure of one angle.

dataSet.name: Observation Table for Angle Sum of Polygons

attributes.name: Angle Sum (S) in degrees
values: 180 * two less than the number of sides OR 180*(n-2)

attributes.name: Angle Sum (S) in degrees
values: 180 * two less than the number of sides OR 180*(n-2)

attributes.name: Measure of an angle in a Regular Polygon (A)
values: Take the angle sum (180(n-2)) and divide it equally among the angles or (180(n-2))/n
